content: Praise Her A Goddess for Invoking Beauty and Sexual Empowerment Aphrodite helps us feel beautiful and honor our sexuality Lisa Marie Blocked Unblock Follow Following Apr 17 Illustration: Cat Finnie S ome people charm whomever they encounter — men, women, kids, even animals. They are vibrant, provocative, and know how to make the subject of their focus feel like a million dollars. They may not be conventionally attractive, but they exude confidence, sex appeal, and magnetism. They are not people-pleasers and prioritize their own pleasure and desires first. Often, they dance to the beat of their own drum. They’re not driven by ambition or the white picket fence; instead, they pursue creative interests and a nontraditional lifestyle. These people walk hand in hand with the Greek goddess Aphrodite. The story of Aphrodite Aphrodite is likely one of the most well-known goddesses in Western culture. She’s the Greek goddess of beauty and love — and yes, sex. There are two stories of Aphrodite’s origin. One tells of her appearing from sea foam, naked and fully formed as a beautiful adult goddess. Another recounts her more traditional upbringing as the daughter of Zeus and his sea nymph mistress, Dione. Aphrodite is both a lover and a mother. She was married to the lame Hephaestus, the god of fire and metalworking, and the son of Zeus and Hera. The union was arranged by Zeus to prevent the other gods from fighting over Aphrodite. Though kind and skilled at his craft, Hephaestus was born deformed and crippled. Aphrodite was not faithful to him and had many other lovers — both gods and men. One of her most passionate, volatile affairs was with Ares, the god of war. They had two sons, Phobos (Panic) and Deimus (Fear), and a beautiful daughter, Harmonia (Harmony). Aphrodite’s other well-known lover was the beautiful mortal Adonis, whom she shared with goddess Persephone for part of each year. Greek goddesses generally fall into one of two categories: the virgin or the vulnerable. In this context, “virgin” means a woman who is “one-in-herself.” She is not owned, influenced, or victimized by a male god or man. In contrast, a vulnerable goddess’s well-being is often determined by the health of her romantic partnerships. The vulnerable goddesses have all suffered in some way by the actions of a male god. Aphrodite, however, doesn’t fit into either category. In Goddesses in Everywoman , Jean Shinoda Bolen places Aphrodite in her own category: alchemical. Alchemy is the process of turning metals into gold. Similarly, Aphrodite can make gods and humans feel beautiful and loved when she focuses her attention on them. She also has the power to make them feel unworthy when her attention wavers. Aphrodite can be fickle. She loves being in love, and when the feeling flees, so does she. Like the virgin goddesses, Aphrodite does what she wants and is not dependent on a man. However, she truly enjoys and takes pleasure from romantic relationships and sexual intimacy. Unlike the vulnerable goddesses, who also desire romantic partnership, she is never victimized by a man. She enters and exits relationships and sexual encounters on her own accord. Aphrodite in modern society When you think of a modern-day Aphrodite, women like Marilyn Monroe or Gigi Hadid may come to mind: dripping in sex appeal, seemingly able to attract any man or woman with a mere sideways glance from her bedroom eyes. However, it’s important to understand that Aphrodite’s appeal is not purely superficial. Many women who are not conventionally attractive have Aphrodite’s allure. It’s their inner sense of sexuality and confidence that is compelling. They know what makes them feel beautiful, and they can make others feel beautiful by shining a spotlight of attention on them. Working with Aphrodite, we can learn that our first priority is to understand and advocate for what we want for ourselves, not others. Aphrodite women seek out sexual experiences not for the benefit of their partner, but on their own behalf. They desire intimacy, connection, and physical touch. Although Aphrodite women fall in love easily, they don’t necessarily stay in love. They live for the present moment and, if not conscious of their tendencies, can chase the initial “in-love” rush over and over again. How Aphrodite works in my life I generally don’t have a hard time connecting with Aphrodite. I love men, sex, and pampering myself. Though I prefer to be in a relationship, I’m pretty independent and I have my own interests and hobbies to pursue. My creative interests, and sometimes my romantic interests, vary; what excites me one year may not the next. However, similar to the vulnerable goddesses, I can grow overly attached to my partner, resulting in clingy and people-pleasing behavior — not Aphrodite-like at all. There are times when I have not honored Aphrodite. Times when I didn’t want to have sex or physical intimacy with a man, but did so anyway because I thought it would make him like me more, or simply because it seemed easier than saying “no.” Most of these experiences happened when I was much younger, but one happened more recently — to my chagrin. I have a daughter who recently started middle school. I’ve already begun to talk to her about boys and sex. In one conversation I explained that kissing and sex are not bad, but she should only do something if and when she wants. Never should she agree to something in an effort to make someone like her, or because she feels obligated. That strategy never, ever works. It’s a conversation I would have liked to have had with my younger self. Aphrodite pursues pleasure on her own terms, not someone else’s. I suspect women sometimes have a hard time saying “no” or asserting what we want because we don’t want to disappoint; we want to be liked. We have some people-pleasing behaviors we need to unlearn. I’m fortunate to now be in a relationship where my partner calls me out on this behavior. Sometimes it is as simple as me being unable to decide where I would like to go for dinner. At first, I stumble and turn the question back to him. When that doesn’t work, I try to think of a place where I know he would like to eat. When he acknowledges my subterfuge, I’m finally forced to think about what I feel like having for dinner and communicate my want. My first inclination, however, is to forfeit my desires for what I think would make him happy. This strategy doesn’t make anyone happy. Working with Aphrodite, we can learn that our first priority is to understand and advocate for what we want for ourselves, not others. Whether we’re trying to determine the level of physical intimacy in which to engage or simply what we want to eat for dinner, we need to check in with our bodies, determine our desires, and follow our intuition. The tantric spiritual guru Osho says, “Always remember to judge everything by your inner feeling of bliss.” I can’t think of a better way to sum up Aphrodite’s philosophy. How you can connect with Aphrodite Cultivate beauty Aphrodite is not an aesthetic to emulate. Throw away the fashion magazines and don’t consider the attractiveness of other women. Stop lamenting over a belly roll or a new wrinkle. Celebrate your unique beauty. That is what makes you attractive. Our culture seems to encourage women to morph into the latest celebrity in order to be considered sexy or desirable. That’s not the path Aphrodite follows. Rather than focusing on external appearances, spend more time creating the feeling of beauty and desirability. You should spend more time cultivating your feelings than your appearance. Creating the feeling of beauty and desirability is different for everyone. That is your path to figure out. The activities that help me feel beautiful are taking baths with essential oils, using decadent moisturizers, and getting massages. Yoga. Eating healthy, seasonally, and locally. And yes, sex with my partner makes me feel beautiful and desirable. Sex appeal cannot be purchased. No matter how sexy your new dress may be, you won’t feel sexy unless you are taking good care of your body and mind. Treat your body as if it were divine, because it is. Connect with your body Most of our time is spent sitting down, typing away on computers. We’re in our heads for much of the day. Take time to feel and reconnect with your body. A 10-minute body scan meditation every day can help you relearn how to assimilate back into your body. Then, rather than thinking your way through situations, you can tap into your inner wisdom by feeling your way and trusting what your body is telling you. Don’t get frustrated if at first you can’t feel your body while doing a body scan. Since so much time is spent in our heads, we need to remember how to connect with our physical bodies — it might take time and practice. Here is a 10-minute body scan meditation on YouTube . Know what turns you on Sex therapist and relationship expert Esther Perel says we need to be able to say “I turn myself on when…” Don’t give that power away to someone else, or hope that he or she will figure it out. They won’t. You need to spend time on your own, learning about your body and what lights you up. Reflect Dedicate some time to connecting with Aphrodite. You might want to start with a quiet walk in nature, a candlelit bath, or a visit to an art museum. Do something that exposes you to beauty. Then set up your meditation area or a quiet space with candles, soothing music, and anything else to create a comfortable and luxurious environment. In your journal, consider: What makes you feel beautiful and sexy? Come up with a list of items. Remember to make sure the items create a feeling, not a look. Practice at least one of the items every day. What turns you on? If you have a partner or lover, talk to them about it. If not, go solo and know you’ll be prepared for the conversation when the time comes. How do you feel about physical intimacy? If you have a date coming up, think about your expectations and boundaries beforehand so you will be more likely to honor them in the moment. What interests you creatively? Are you pursuing it? If not, why? I wish you love, beauty, and bliss on your journey.
title_html: A Goddess for Invoking Beauty and Sexual Empowerment
html:

Praise Her

A Goddess for Invoking Beauty and Sexual Empowerment

Aphrodite helps us feel beautiful and honor our sexuality

Lisa Marie
Apr 17

Some people charm whomever they encounter — men, women, kids, even animals. They are vibrant, provocative, and know how to make the subject of their focus feel like a million dollars. They may not be conventionally attractive, but they exude confidence, sex appeal, and magnetism. They are not people-pleasers and prioritize their own pleasure and desires first. Often, they dance to the beat of their own drum. They’re not driven by ambition or the white picket fence; instead, they pursue creative interests and a nontraditional lifestyle. These people walk hand in hand with the Greek goddess Aphrodite.

The story of Aphrodite

Aphrodite is likely one of the most well-known goddesses in Western culture. She’s the Greek goddess of beauty and love — and yes, sex. There are two stories of Aphrodite’s origin. One tells of her appearing from sea foam, naked and fully formed as a beautiful adult goddess. Another recounts her more traditional upbringing as the daughter of Zeus and his sea nymph mistress, Dione.

Aphrodite is both a lover and a mother. She was married to the lame Hephaestus, the god of fire and metalworking, and the son of Zeus and Hera. The union was arranged by Zeus to prevent the other gods from fighting over Aphrodite. Though kind and skilled at his craft, Hephaestus was born deformed and crippled. Aphrodite was not faithful to him and had many other lovers — both gods and men. One of her most passionate, volatile affairs was with Ares, the god of war. They had two sons, Phobos (Panic) and Deimus (Fear), and a beautiful daughter, Harmonia (Harmony). Aphrodite’s other well-known lover was the beautiful mortal Adonis, whom she shared with goddess Persephone for part of each year.

Greek goddesses generally fall into one of two categories: the virgin or the vulnerable. In this context, “virgin” means a woman who is “one-in-herself.” She is not owned, influenced, or victimized by a male god or man. In contrast, a vulnerable goddess’s well-being is often determined by the health of her romantic partnerships. The vulnerable goddesses have all suffered in some way by the actions of a male god. Aphrodite, however, doesn’t fit into either category. In Goddesses in Everywoman, Jean Shinoda Bolen places Aphrodite in her own category: alchemical. Alchemy is the process of turning metals into gold. Similarly, Aphrodite can make gods and humans feel beautiful and loved when she focuses her attention on them. She also has the power to make them feel unworthy when her attention wavers. Aphrodite can be fickle. She loves being in love, and when the feeling flees, so does she.

Like the virgin goddesses, Aphrodite does what she wants and is not dependent on a man. However, she truly enjoys and takes pleasure from romantic relationships and sexual intimacy. Unlike the vulnerable goddesses, who also desire romantic partnership, she is never victimized by a man. She enters and exits relationships and sexual encounters on her own accord.

Aphrodite in modern society

When you think of a modern-day Aphrodite, women like Marilyn Monroe or Gigi Hadid may come to mind: dripping in sex appeal, seemingly able to attract any man or woman with a mere sideways glance from her bedroom eyes. However, it’s important to understand that Aphrodite’s appeal is not purely superficial. Many women who are not conventionally attractive have Aphrodite’s allure. It’s their inner sense of sexuality and confidence that is compelling. They know what makes them feel beautiful, and they can make others feel beautiful by shining a spotlight of attention on them.

Working with Aphrodite, we can learn that our first priority is to understand and advocate for what we want for ourselves, not others.

Aphrodite women seek out sexual experiences not for the benefit of their partner, but on their own behalf. They desire intimacy, connection, and physical touch. Although Aphrodite women fall in love easily, they don’t necessarily stay in love. They live for the present moment and, if not conscious of their tendencies, can chase the initial “in-love” rush over and over again.

How Aphrodite works in my life

I generally don’t have a hard time connecting with Aphrodite. I love men, sex, and pampering myself. Though I prefer to be in a relationship, I’m pretty independent and I have my own interests and hobbies to pursue. My creative interests, and sometimes my romantic interests, vary; what excites me one year may not the next. However, similar to the vulnerable goddesses, I can grow overly attached to my partner, resulting in clingy and people-pleasing behavior — not Aphrodite-like at all.

There are times when I have not honored Aphrodite. Times when I didn’t want to have sex or physical intimacy with a man, but did so anyway because I thought it would make him like me more, or simply because it seemed easier than saying “no.” Most of these experiences happened when I was much younger, but one happened more recently — to my chagrin.

I have a daughter who recently started middle school. I’ve already begun to talk to her about boys and sex. In one conversation I explained that kissing and sex are not bad, but she should only do something if and when she wants. Never should she agree to something in an effort to make someone like her, or because she feels obligated. That strategy never, ever works. It’s a conversation I would have liked to have had with my younger self. Aphrodite pursues pleasure on her own terms, not someone else’s.

I suspect women sometimes have a hard time saying “no” or asserting what we want because we don’t want to disappoint; we want to be liked. We have some people-pleasing behaviors we need to unlearn. I’m fortunate to now be in a relationship where my partner calls me out on this behavior. Sometimes it is as simple as me being unable to decide where I would like to go for dinner. At first, I stumble and turn the question back to him. When that doesn’t work, I try to think of a place where I know he would like to eat. When he acknowledges my subterfuge, I’m finally forced to think about what I feel like having for dinner and communicate my want. My first inclination, however, is to forfeit my desires for what I think would make him happy. This strategy doesn’t make anyone happy.

Working with Aphrodite, we can learn that our first priority is to understand and advocate for what we want for ourselves, not others. Whether we’re trying to determine the level of physical intimacy in which to engage or simply what we want to eat for dinner, we need to check in with our bodies, determine our desires, and follow our intuition.

The tantric spiritual guru Osho says, “Always remember to judge everything by your inner feeling of bliss.” I can’t think of a better way to sum up Aphrodite’s philosophy.

How you can connect with Aphrodite

Cultivate beauty

Aphrodite is not an aesthetic to emulate. Throw away the fashion magazines and don’t consider the attractiveness of other women. Stop lamenting over a belly roll or a new wrinkle. Celebrate your unique beauty. That is what makes you attractive. Our culture seems to encourage women to morph into the latest celebrity in order to be considered sexy or desirable. That’s not the path Aphrodite follows. Rather than focusing on external appearances, spend more time creating the feeling of beauty and desirability. You should spend more time cultivating your feelings than your appearance.

Creating the feeling of beauty and desirability is different for everyone. That is your path to figure out. The activities that help me feel beautiful are taking baths with essential oils, using decadent moisturizers, and getting massages. Yoga. Eating healthy, seasonally, and locally. And yes, sex with my partner makes me feel beautiful and desirable. Sex appeal cannot be purchased. No matter how sexy your new dress may be, you won’t feel sexy unless you are taking good care of your body and mind. Treat your body as if it were divine, because it is.

Connect with your body

Most of our time is spent sitting down, typing away on computers. We’re in our heads for much of the day. Take time to feel and reconnect with your body. A 10-minute body scan meditation every day can help you relearn how to assimilate back into your body. Then, rather than thinking your way through situations, you can tap into your inner wisdom by feeling your way and trusting what your body is telling you. Don’t get frustrated if at first you can’t feel your body while doing a body scan. Since so much time is spent in our heads, we need to remember how to connect with our physical bodies — it might take time and practice. Here is a 10-minute body scan meditation on YouTube.

Know what turns you on

Sex therapist and relationship expert Esther Perel says we need to be able to say “I turn myself on when…” Don’t give that power away to someone else, or hope that he or she will figure it out. They won’t. You need to spend time on your own, learning about your body and what lights you up.

Reflect

Dedicate some time to connecting with Aphrodite. You might want to start with a quiet walk in nature, a candlelit bath, or a visit to an art museum. Do something that exposes you to beauty. Then set up your meditation area or a quiet space with candles, soothing music, and anything else to create a comfortable and luxurious environment. In your journal, consider:

  • What makes you feel beautiful and sexy? Come up with a list of items. Remember to make sure the items create a feeling, not a look. Practice at least one of the items every day.
  • What turns you on? If you have a partner or lover, talk to them about it. If not, go solo and know you’ll be prepared for the conversation when the time comes.
  • How do you feel about physical intimacy? If you have a date coming up, think about your expectations and boundaries beforehand so you will be more likely to honor them in the moment.
  • What interests you creatively? Are you pursuing it? If not, why?

I wish you love, beauty, and bliss on your journey.

    Medium member since Feb 2019

    Mom. Yogini. Designer. Seeking peace through bliss, kindness, and good skincare. 🧘‍♀️ 🙏🏻 IG:@mindbodylisa www.goddessyogashala.com

title: A Goddess for Invoking Beauty and Sexual Empowerment
content_html:
Praise Her

A Goddess for Invoking Beauty and Sexual Empowerment

Aphrodite helps us feel beautiful and honor our sexuality

Lisa Marie
Apr 17

Some people charm whomever they encounter — men, women, kids, even animals. They are vibrant, provocative, and know how to make the subject of their focus feel like a million dollars. They may not be conventionally attractive, but they exude confidence, sex appeal, and magnetism. They are not people-pleasers and prioritize their own pleasure and desires first.   • What interests you creatively? Are you pursuing it? If not, why?

I wish you love, beauty, and bliss on your journey.
